description:
Artibeus jamaicensis, commonly known as the Jamaican fruit bat, is a species of bat belonging to the family Phyllostomidae. It is a medium-sized bat found throughout the Caribbean region, including the islands of Jamaica, Cuba, Hispaniola, and Puerto Rico.

The Jamaican fruit bat has a robust, stocky build with a broad head and large eyes. It has a wingspan ranging from 30 to 40 cm and weighs between 40 to 70 grams. The fur is typically dark brown or blackish in color, with a pale-colored abdomen. The species is characterized by its distinctive noseleaf, which is a fleshy, leaf-like structure on the nose that helps in echolocation and navigation.

Artibeus jamaicensis is an important pollinator and seed disperser, playing a crucial role in the ecosystem. It feeds primarily on various fruits, including bananas, mangoes, and figs, as well as nectar and pollen from flowers. The species is known to roost in caves, abandoned buildings, and dense foliage, often forming large colonies.

The Jamaican fruit bat is generally considered a common and widespread species throughout its range, although populations may be affected by habitat loss and fragmentation. Conservation efforts focus on protecting roosting sites and maintaining a healthy balance of the species' natural food sources.
